channel.title: Horse meat
channel.description:
I'm shocked at you guys. Not a single mention of this controversy yet.
So as most of you are aware, in some beef-containing products - particularly ready meals - horse meat (and also supposedly donkey meat) has been found - one Lasange was found to have 99% horse meat.
How does this make you guys feel? How do you think the laws should be changed? How do we know what else goes into these meals? Would you try horse meat?
Discuss.

item.title: Horse meat

item.description:

It’s really not that serious… lol.
[/quote]

Supermarkets, selling meat that they have no idea is safe for human consumption, from unknown sources, is not really all that serious. ~ -Nothing, 2013[/quote]
It really isn’t.

most people eat cow (beef) and chicken, deer (venison) etc, and people choose horse to fuss over? jesus christ chinamen eat cats and germans love dogs WHY ARE WE ARGUING ABOUT HORSE M8

item.title: Horse meat
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

LilXCj:

Is this a moral debate about whether we should eat horse or just a debate about what the food companies should actually be doing because the meat is horse meat and is labeled as something else?

I view it as a health and ethical debate, the companies had no idea where the meat was from or what was in the meat or whether it was even safe for human consumption

Read full topic

item.title: Horse meat
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“jme, post:41, topic:483186”]Those ready-meals are such garbage anyways, I would glady accept one that contains 99% horse-meat, since most are just fake beef with potato or bread filler.

I love deer, moose etc, I’m sure horse is similar. But if I buy beef, I want beef. There’s probably not much to discuss, everyone knows it’s very unethical to mislead people about products and especially food products. And imo, there should be criminal charges for this.[/quote]
Horse isn’t bad meat, you just have to know the source.

Read full topic

item.title: Horse meat
item.dc:creator: @Christmas_tree Christmas_tree
item.description:
@Christmas_tree wrote:

[quote=“imthenull, post:38, topic:483186”][quote author=Niall link=topic=601421.msg4220266#msg4220266 date=1360697432]

http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/tesco-admits-its-everyday-value-spaghetti-bolognese-was-more-than-60-horsemeat-8489787.html

Well then… I guess that clears everything up. Tbh if it takes good then people need to stop complaining, but they should also be aware of what they’re eating. Being lied to is never fun, but when things like eating horse instead of cow (assuming there is no major difference in nutrients) should not be a public catastrophe lol.

are you so dense that you can’t see the real issue? it’s not that people were being lied to or even that horse meat was being sold the issue is that the horse meat was being sold unknowingly

the fact that the source of the horse meat is still unknown is extremely worrying as well, if supermarkets and ready meal producers don’t know what their products contain then why the hell should people ever trust them again? people RELY on food being sold to be exactly what it is, it’s quite literally a matter of life and death for some people
[/quote]
nonetheless religious shit.[/quote]

What even are you talking about. If you wish to bring up how this is a conflict within religious societies please do so. But don’t just talk out your ass

Read full topic

item.title: Horse meat
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

[quote=“Elrick, post:36, topic:483186”][quote author=imthenull link=topic=601421.msg4220238#msg4220238 date=1360696212]

The Independent – 11 Feb 13

Tesco admits its Everyday Value Spaghetti Bolognese was more than 60%

Tesco has revealed tonight that some of its frozen Everyday Value Spaghetti Bolognese contains more than 60 per cent horsemeat.


[/quote]
Well then… I guess that clears everything up. Tbh if it takes good then people need to stop complaining, but they should also be aware of what they’re eating. Being lied to is never fun, but when things like eating horse instead of cow (assuming there is no major difference in nutrients) should not be a public catastrophe lol.[/quote]

are you so dense that you can’t see the real issue? it’s not that people were being lied to or even that horse meat was being sold the issue is that the horse meat was being sold unknowingly

the fact that the source of the horse meat is still unknown is extremely worrying as well, if supermarkets and ready meal producers don’t know what their products contain then why the hell should people ever trust them again? people RELY on food being sold to be exactly what it is, it’s quite literally a matter of life and death for some people

Read full topic

item.title: Horse meat
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“imthenull, post:32, topic:483186”][quote author=Niall link=topic=601421.msg4220186#msg4220186 date=1360694974]

There is a huge problem if these accusations are true.

they aren’t accusations, ready meals were found to contain (up to) 100% horse meat labelled as 100% beef meat, the supermarkets and people preparing the meals blatantly admitted they had no idea what type of meat they were getting or where it came from, the issue with this whole controversy is that no one knows where the meat being sold was “harvested” or whether it was even safe for human consumption, love ups this bad can very easily lead to a lot of people being killed
[/quote]
Right, then like you and myself have stated, this is a huge problem. I hope this will call for a ‘revolution’ for these companies that produces these types of food, similar to Taco Bell’s fraudulent beef case.

Yet another reason to only trust meat from your own country.

In the US all food is regulated by the FDA.[/quote]
I know Ruby would kill me for this, but why should I trust FDA?

Our European neighbor should now stop comparing Norway to USSR just because we want to protect ourself from foreign farm products.

Read full topic
